A German Trade Commission is expected to arrive at Bucharest this week. It is thought that oil and minerals will be dis- cussed. Herr Clodius, Chief Economic Secretary to the German Foreign Office, who is in Bucharest, told German journalists that the existing commercial arrangements with Rumania expired on 1st October and new quotas needed to be fixed. The harbour of Gdynia, the Polish port captured by German troops, is to be used for the export of coal from Upper Silesia, the official German news agency states. This will be possible when the railways have been repaired.-Reuter. COPENHAGEN, 16th Sept. A German trade delegation has gone to Moscow to extend the trade agreements between Germany and Russia, according to the " Berlingske Tidende " to-day. It is understood, says the paper, that the Germans are prepared to double their credit to the Soviets.-Reuter. on on ou Pr ou the pri ha We W1 tho ini thi un in of Ch au,

Cycle manufacturers have unanimously agreed that it is necessary to ad- vance retail prices by at least 12Y per cent. immediately. London makers are expected to advance their prices by about 20 per cent., as they are geographically badly placed for cycle production.

London Metal Exchange dealers are hoping that the market chaos resulting from the outbreak of war will shortly be resolved, and that in consequence they will be able to satisfy the large number of accumulated trade in- quiries. Dealers will arrive in the City to- day not knowing whether the Ex- change will be reopened for trading limited to tin or whether the shut- down will be postponed further at the request of the Government. Since the commencement of hostili- ties, dealings in copper, lead and spelter have been suspended. The Exchange was opened on 6th Septem- ber for business in tin, but so heavy was the turnover and so wide the price discrepancies that the London and Eastern markets were closed by official request last Wednesday. ANGLO-U.S. TIN TALKS Heavy restocking purchases in the United States forced the American price far out of line with the maximum of Â£230 for standard metal envisaged by the Buffer Pool. Apart from the fact that Straits tin was changing hands at well over Â£300 a ton in the United States, it had been reported that London traders with export licenses were able to buy Chinese tin here at Â£230 a ton and sell in New York at Â£295 a ton. To mitigate these anomalies discussions are believed to have been taking place between the British and American Govern- ments and representatives of the tin control. Upon whether an understanding has been reached between the parties con- cerned depends, it is thought, the re- opening of the market. One result expected by some observers is the fixing of a maximum London price in excess of Â£230 a ton. An increase of perhaps Â£20 a ton would not be surprising in view of the depreciatioi of sterling. EMPIRE METAL SUPPLIES There is as yet no sign that trading in copper, lead and zinc will be resumed. One explanation for the delay is that the Government wishes first to complete a number of important contracts with Empire producers. It is reasonable to assume that before arranging for supplies through the London Metal Exchange this country should know what the Empire countries can supply-and at what price- and what those countries' own require- ments may be. Wartime expansion of Canadian and Australian industries, for example, should make abnormally heavy demands on the dominions' base metal pro- duction. These are wise precautions, but dealers hope that the fact-finding process will be completed as soon as possible. The market has other difficulties to face. One of these arises from the precautionary diversion of metal cargoes to other than their normal U.K. ports. Who shall carry the burden of consequent additional transport costs is un- decided; some dealers urge that the insurers are liable. Editorial comment Page 2 Col. 1

SINGAPORE, 17th Sept. Using his powers under the defence regulations, Sir Thomas Shenton Thomas, Governor of the Straits Settlements, has issued a tin control order. No person can now buy, sell or agree to offer to buy or sell unwrought tin in blocks, ingots, bars or slabs at a price ex- ceeding the Malayan currency . parity equivalent of Â£230 per ton on the usual terms of delivery from Malayan smelters. The tin market is opening on Monday.- Ex. Tel.

From OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT PERTH (W.A.), 17th Sept. Strong condemnation of the Federal tax on gold-mining companies of 75 per cent. on the excess gold price above Â£A.9 per ounce is voiced by Mr. J. C. Willcock, Premier of Western Australia. He points out that no account is taken of whether the mines are payable or unpayable, or prospectors prosperous or poor. The Federal Government, he continues, had its eyes turned months ago to Western Australia's valuable gold output. When a tax was then suggested he told the Federal authorities that it would injure the industry and it was thought that the proposal had been abandoned until the Government " bombshell " burst in the Federal House on Friday. A strong protest against the imposition of the tax is being forwarded by the State Chamber of Mines to the Federal authorities. Mining industry leaders describe the tax as a "monstrous injustice to Western Australia." On the basis of the 1938 Commonwealth gold production it is computed that the State will pay more than three-quarters of the tax.

It is understood that the major Cana- dian newsprint companies will also re- affirm their domestic prices for the first quarter of 1940. On Friday the Inter- national Paper Company, of New York, reaffirmed for the March quarter its news- print price of $50 (about Â£12 10s) per ton delivered New York/Chicago.-Reuter.

HONG KONG, 16th Sept. Mr. T. V. Soong, chairman of the Bank of China, has left here for Chungking, seat of the Chinese Government. Former Minister of Finance, Mr. Soong paid a secret visit to Chungking on 7th September. The principal object was believed to have been the discussion of ways and means to bolster up China's economic war against Japan.-Reuter.

Japan's foreign trade for August con. sisted of exports valued at 377 million yen, an increase of 33 million yen com- pared with the preceding month and of 118 million yen over August, 1938. Im- ports amounted to 246 million yen, against 264 million yen m .July and 206 million yen in August, 1938. Excess of exports were thus 131. million yen, compared with 80 million yen in the previous month and 58 million yen in August, 1988.
The coupons due 1st October of the Spanish Four per Cent. Debt can be pre sented for payment at the Bank of Spain, Bilbao House, E.C.

article_dc_title: Total of British Vessels Reported Sunk by Enemy Craft since the War Began, on Saturday Reached 21, Involving a Tonnage of 122,843
text_content: TotaW of British vessels reported sunk by enemy craft since the war began, on Saturday reaohed 21, involving a tonnage of 122,848.

By THE MINING EDITOR There being a larger ratio of specu- lative dealings in the Mining markets than in any other section-outside, I suppose, Yankees-it is not surpris- ing that it is taking some time to complete the transition from Account to cash dealings. As late as last Friday there was still some forced closing reported in Kaffirs. I gather that certain weakish positions in Johannesburg and Paris have also been liquidated. After the Settlement due this Thursday jobbers will have a good deal of stock de- livered to them and in such cases should be able to quote closer prices for cash dealings than was, as a rule, possible last week. MANY OBSCURITIES There are inevitably still many obscuri- ties in the outlook for both gold and base- metal companies. In particular maximum prices for copper, tin, lead and zinc have yet to be officially announced. Sales of uncut diamonds by the Diamond Trading Company have, I believe, been suspended for the time being and it is feared that new production from South Africa may be stopped. However, the Consolidated African Selection Trust may continue shipping industrial diamonds from its properties in West Africa. GOLD PRICE As regards gold the position is becoming clearer. We are still awaiting news of any definite decision regarding West African and Indian producers. Possibly the local authorities will be satisfied with the large sums already taken in royalty, etc., while H.M. Government may take its share of any increase in profits by E.P.D. on these English-registered companies. Meantime Australia has followed South Africa and Southern Rhodes;n by, in effect, fixing her buying price from the mines at 150s sterling. This is equivalent to 187, 6d in Australian currency, against last year's average of 178s 1d. Unlike the other countries, Australia will, how- ever, permit her mines to receive one- quarter of any fresh rise in the price of gold which may conceivably occur even- tually. BANGRIN TIN In view of the substantial increase in the tin quota and even on the assumption that the price of the metal is maintained at only Â£230 per ton, it is felt that most Tin shares have scope for recovery as and when market conditions become more normal. Tin shares were depressed in the first half of this year owing to the low quotas ruling. Therefore in regard to this metal it is not so much a case of companies making any inordinate profits as a result of current conditions, but more of being able to produce a reasonable quota and sell it at a fair price. As already announced in THE FINANCIAL TIMES, the quota for the third quarter has been fixed at 80 per cent. This compares with the first quarter of 40 per cent. and the second quarter of 45 per cent. The fourth quarter is at present fixed at 60 per cent., but may be adjusted in accord- ance with the developments of the next month or so. Bangrin Tin Dredging Â£1 units, if obtainable at anything up topar, are con- sidered a good purchase. For 1938 the company paid 10 per cent., as against 15 per cent. for the previous year. For the first six months of the current year the working profit has been published as Â£34,000, or just over 10 per cent. on the capital Still better results would seem reason- ably assured for the second half of the year. Thus the dividend should at least be maintained, with the possibility of some increase. The company's balance-sheet shows a strong position, liquid assets amounting to Â£94,000. There is a good life ahead of the property, additional areas having been obtained during recent years.

OTTAWA, 16th Sept. Measures for the control of foreign exchange have been announced by the- new Minister for Finance, Colonel J. L. Ralston. A Board headed by Mr. Graham Towers, governor of Bank of Canada, has been created with power to license the exports and imports of goods of all kinds, including money and securities. An additional Order in Council makes effective certain provisions of the Ex- change Fund Act providing for the use of the Exchange Fund created in 1935 by the revaluation of gold. Colonel Ralston stated that the use of the Fund would enaule the Government through the exchange control to assist the import and export trade by maintain- ing more stable exchange rates than would otherwise be possible. The Bank of Canada announces the fol- lowing rates for to-day under the new Ex- change Control Board:- New York Funds-Buying 10 per cent. premium; selling 11 per cent. premium. Sterling-Buying 4.42 Canadian dollars; selling $4.46.-Ex. Tel.

Rates on coal cargoes from South Wales c ports to some destinations have jumped T 100 per cent. since the war started. The b ace is set by neutrals, whose rates cannot t bcontrolled, and a free market exists â regarding freights. Ships are being chartered for coal to f, South America at 20s a ton, against 10s a to Rio de Janeiro 10 days ago. The rate to Lisbon has advanced from 9s to 16s, to a Port Said from 9s 6d to 15s, to Bordeaux b from 4s 6d to 10s and to Alexandria from 10s to 17s 6d. These high freights do not represent abnormal profits for shipowners; but that t investors believe they will benefit materially is reflected in the rise in b Shipping shares. The Stock Market value of the shares of six leading Welsh com- panies has advanced Â£600,000 since the i war began. I_ . . .. . . . . . . . . . . . . .

From OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT DUNDEE, Saturday. Jute business has been practically at a standstill during the past week and the market is awaiting fresh controlled prices. Spinners cannot buy raw jute and they are refusing to sell yarns at the rates ruling under the Control Order dated 1st September, which fixed the maximum value of common 8-lb cops at 2s 8d. Raw jute has advanced considerably in Calcutta, while fluctuating to some extent, but it is now reported from that centre that the Indian jute mills have agreed that not more than Rs.9% per maund for European jute and Rs.9% for native jute will be paid. It is expected that the Indian Government will co-operate with Dundee in the fixing of maximum prices for raw jute and also for Calcutta goods, which will end the speculation which has been going on in Calcutta since the beginning of this month.

The recent strength of Argentine Rail stocks reflects the belief that benefits will accrue from increased deliveries of foodstuffs and raw materials to Great Britain and her allies. Purchasers envisage a repetition of the conditions prevailing during the last war when Argentina and the rail- ways profited by exceptionally heavy shipments of wheat, maize, meat and linseed to the Allies. Those in close touch with the railways are more cautious, stressing that condi- tions are not strictly comparable. They point to many uncertainties in the present situation, including the duration of the war, the variation of crops, the avail- ability of shipping space and possible changes in the peso rate and fluctuation in railway costs. As in the Great War the cost of coal and other materials for the railways will pre- sumably be increased. Unlike 1914 there is now road competition which may limit any increase of rates or reduce the rail- ways' share of expanded trade. CEREAL REQUIREMENTS Supplies likely to be required by this country include wheat, maize, linseed and meat. Ports are stacked with cereals. Heavy shipments could take place without bringing extra trafic to the railways; but there are substantial supplies up-country which could be railed in case of need. Shipments to this country in the near future must be limited. For at the moment all the grain storage capacity in this country is filled. And some delay is un- avoidable before the convoy system can be fully worked out. As regards new crop prospects, it is too early to make accurate estimates. There is no maize left from the current crop and the new crop cannot be estimated until the end of February. Linseed supplies cannot be gauged before the end of December; wheat until the end of November. So far as meat is concerned, if rationing is imposed on the same scale as during the last war, this country would not require much from the Argentine for home con- sumption. Our needs might well be met from Canada and the United States. But if the war is of long duration and Great Britain has to retain large forces overseas there may be a heavy call on Argentine resources. On general grounds, Argentine trade prospects appear relatively bright. The trade balance has improved stbstantially this year compared with last. For the first six months of 1939 there was a favourable balance of 191,194,000 pesos as compared with an adverse balance of 34,768,000 pesos in the first half of 1938. War in Europe should improve prospects of supplying Allied countries and raise prices for Argentine produce, though the Republic will lose a large part of her trade with Germany, which normally is one of her best customers. The public rate of exchange has im- proved during the past week, though the railways rate remains unaltered at rather more than 16 pesos to the Â£. It seems, nevertheless, that the country's financial position may be strengthened, and this would naturally make the Government less disinclined to grant more reasonable facili- ties to the railways. But it is as well to remember that, despite the greater volume of goods carried to ports on Allied a -ount during the Great War, the dividends of the leading railway companies showed no remarkable improve- ment.
